Award.AwardTitle: CCF-BSF:CIF:Small:Signal Processing and Machine Learning on Manifolds, with Applications to Invariant Detection and Covariant Estimation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
In many fields of engineering and applied science the problem is to extract relevant information from a signal or image. Certainly this describes the problem of identifying cyber attackers in data networks, spotting objects of interest in closed-circuit TV records, and classifying anomalies in medical images. The goal of this project is to develop a signal processing theory for detecting and classifying images that have undergone geometric transformations. Practical and topical examples are medical features viewed in variable magnification and orientation, and images of people in arbitrary orientations in crowded scenes. The solution to classification problems under such imaging conditions will advance medical practice and national defense. As a broader impact, the project prepares students for careers in mathematics and electrical engineering, with an expertise in signal processing and imaging science.

This project develops a theory of matched manifold detectors, based on a universal manifold embedding that extracts a subspace basis from an image. The basis itself codes for the coordinate transformation of the image, but its span is invariant to the transformation. Consequently the extracted subspace is an invariant statistic for detection, and the basis is a covariant statistic for the parameters of the transformation. Classification is then a problem of subspace matching on a Grassmann manifold, and identification of coordinate transformation is a problem of analyzing a subspace basis in a Stiefel manifold. We aim to adapt this theory to other problems where a transformation group turns out an orbit of images, all of which are to be classified as equivalent. The objective is to develop a theory of signal processing on manifolds that is as broad in its scope and as precise in its methodologies as modern subspace signal processing. Such a theory will augment statistical reasoning with geometrical reasoning, and bring new mathematical methods into play.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Objects of interest in medicine and surveillance reveal themselves through the images they form. Changing the pose of an object with respect to an imaging system changes the formed image. The standout questions are these: Are there features that can be used to determine the change in pose? Are there features that remain unchanged with a change in pose? The first kind of feature is called covariant, as it changes as the object changes pose; the second kind is called invariant, as it remains invariant to a change in pose. Covariant feature are used to track changes in pose of an object; invariant feature are used to classify an object under all changes in pose. Another challenge is to design a classifier that uses invariant features to decide whether the imaged object is benign or malignant. 

Representation theory studies the way a change in pose, construed quite generally, changes a measurement. It guides the selection of covariant features and invariant features, generalizing matched and adaptive signal processing to machine learning and image processing. This goal, one of the main goals of the project, has been achieved.

In this program the investigators have identified covariant and invariant image features for several types of imaging problems. Then using principles from physics, information theory, and statistics, they have designed classifiers that are functions of the invariant features. In all cases the classifiers have compelling geometrical interpretations.

These are the technical achievements. But another goal of this project was to establish a close working relationship between engineers and mathematicians, with the stated aim of harmonizing their particular dialects of the scientific language into a shared, expressive, language. This goal has been achieved.

The net of this research program is to lay the foundations for extending the theory of covariant estimation and invariant detection from the classical domains of communication, radar, geophysics, and radio astronomy to new domains of image processing and machine learning for big data. 

Objects of interest in medicine and surveillance reveal themselves through the images they form. To change the pose of an object with respect to an imaging system is to change the formed image. The standout questions are these: are there features of the image that can be used to determine the change in pose? Are there features of the image that remain unchanged with a change in pose? The first kind of feature is called a covariant feature, as it changes as the object changes pose; the second kind is called an invariant feature, as it remains invariant to a change in pose. The value of a covariant feature is that it may be used to track changes in pose of an object; the value of an invariant feature is that it may be used to classify an object under all changes in pose.

Representation theory is a mathematic theory for studying the way a change in pose, construed quite generally, changes a measurement.  It guides the selection of covariant features and invariant features. It guides the generalization of matched and adaptive signal processing to matched and adaptive machine learning and image processing. This generalization was one of the main goals of the proposed research program. The goal has been achieved.

The first technical challenge is to identify covariant features. The second is to construct invariant features as functions of these covariant features. The third technical challenge is to design a classifier that uses invariant features to decide whether the imaged object is benign or malignant. Friend or foe?

In this program the investigators have identified covariant and invariant image features for several types of imaging problems. Then using principles from physics, information theory, and statistics, they have designed classifiers that are functions of the invariant features. In all cases the classifiers have compelling geometrical interpretations.

For one class of imaging problems studied in this program, the covariant features identify an unknown scaling and rotation; the invariant features identify the origin of the image before scaling and rotation. For other classes of images, the covariant features identify even more general transformations of an image, and the invariant features identify the origin of the image. These results have implications for surveillance and medical imaging.

These are the technical achievements. But another goal of this project was to establish a close working relationship between engineers and mathematicians, with the stated aim of harmonizing their particular dialects of the scientific language into a shared, expressive, language. This goal has been achieved.

The net of this research program is to lay the foundations for extending the theory of covariant estimation and invariant detection from the classical domains of communication, radar, geophysics, and radio astronomy to new domains of image processing and machine learning for big data.
